definition:
Let $X$ and $Y$ be metric spaces. A family $F$ of functions from $X$ to
$Y$ is said to be *equibounded* if there exists a bounded subset $B$ of
$Y$ such that for all $f\in F$ and all $x\in X$ it holds $f(x)\in B$.

Notice that if $F\subset \mathcal C_b(X,Y)$ (continuous bounded
functions) then $F$ is equibounded if and only if $F$ is bounded (with
respect to the metric of uniform convergence).
